perturbation.original_text: The Breaching Party shall have sixty (60) days (thirty (30) days in the event of non-payment) after written notice thereof was provided to the Breaching Party by the non-breaching Party to remedy such default. Unless the Breaching Party has cured any such breach or default prior to the expiration of such sixty (60) day period (thirty (30) day period for non-payment), such termination shall become effective upon receipt of the written notice of termination by the Breaching Party to be given within ten (10) days of the end of such sixty (60) day period (thirty (30) day period for non-payment).
perturbation.changed_text: The Breaching Party shall have fifteen (15) days (seven (7) days in the event of non-payment) after written notice thereof was provided to the Breaching Party by the non-breaching Party to remedy such default. Unless the Breaching Party has cured any such breach or default prior to the expiration of such fifteen (15) day period (seven (7) day period for non-payment), such termination shall become effective upon receipt of the written notice of termination by the Breaching Party to be given within five (5) days of the end of such fifteen (15) day period (seven (7) day period for non-payment).
perturbation.explanation: This change reduces the cure period for a material breach and non-payment, potentially violating legal standards that require a reasonable opportunity to cure before contract termination. Courts often require a reasonable timeframe, and such a short timeframe might be deemed unreasonable.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General Contract Law - Reasonable Cure Period

perturbation.original_text: Xencor shall have the right, upon [***] ([***]) days' prior written notice to Aimmune, to cause an independent, certified international public accounting firm reasonably acceptable to Aimmune or reasonably acceptable to its Affiliates or Sublicensees, as applicable, to audit such records during Aimmune's, or its Affiliate's or Sublicensees', as applicable, normal business hours to confirm the number of Product units sold, the gross sales and Net Sales of Product, the royalties payable, the method used to calculate the royalties payable, and the exchange rates used in accordance with Section 8.2. The audit shall be limited to pertinent records kept by Aimmune and its Affiliates and Sublicensees for any year ending not more than [***] ([***]) months prior to the date of the written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: Xencor shall have the right, upon two (2) days' prior written notice to Aimmune, to cause an independent, uncertified local accounting firm chosen solely by Xencor to audit such records at any time, including outside of normal business hours, to confirm the number of Product units sold, the gross sales and Net Sales of Product, the royalties payable, the method used to calculate the royalties payable, and the exchange rates used in accordance with Section 8.2. The audit shall include all records, regardless of relevance, kept by Aimmune and its Affiliates and Sublicensees from the inception of this agreement.
perturbation.explanation: This change makes the audit terms unreasonable and potentially violates privacy laws. Reducing the notice period, allowing audits outside business hours, using an uncertified firm, and demanding irrelevant records introduce non-compliance.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Data privacy laws, contract law principles of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text: The Parties agree that during the Term, and for a period of [***] ([***]) years thereafter, a Party receiving Confidential Information of the other Party will (X) maintain in confidence such Confidential Information to the same extent such Party maintains its own proprietary information of similar kind and value, and, in any event, no less than a reasonable standard of care, (Y) not disclose such Confidential Information to any Third Party without the prior written consent of the other Party, except as otherwise expressly permitted below, and (Z) not use such Confidential Information for any purpose except those permitted by this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: The Parties agree that during the Term, and for a period of ninety (90) days thereafter, a Party receiving Confidential Information of the other Party will (X) maintain in confidence such Confidential Information to the same extent such Party maintains its own proprietary information of similar kind and value, and, in any event, no less than a reasonable standard of care, (Y) not disclose such Confidential Information to any Third Party without the prior written consent of the other Party, except as otherwise expressly permitted below, and (Z) not use such Confidential Information for any purpose except those permitted by this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the confidentiality period to 90 days is unreasonable for trade secrets and proprietary information, conflicting with standard practice and legal protections for intellectual property. Trade secrets require protection for as long as they remain secret and provide a competitive advantage.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Trade Secret Law, Uniform Trade Secrets Act
